location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita tiene 46 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en una casa alquilada junto a su hijo menor Jefferson de 13 años y lo que más desea es sobresalir en la vida. La carnicería de Margarita está ubicada en el mercado Tupac Amaru (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), su puesto es muy concurrido, pues sus clientes saben que la calidad de carne que vende es muy buena y que están comprando algo sabroso para comer, esto se debe a que Margarita es muy cuidadosa para elegir la carne que vende. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes, tiene 16 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta sin poder salir. Para el futuro espera que su negocio crezca y le brinde mejores ingresos económicos.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Margarita con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, puesto que no quiere perjudicar a las demás socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida por la alegría que le pone al grupo. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más carne para aumentar la cantidad que vende normalmente.
texts.en:
Margarita is a hard-working 46-year-old woman who lives in a rented house with her youngest son, Jefferson, who is 13. Her greatest wish is to excel in life.

Margarita's butcher shop is located in the Tupac Amaru market (a major market in the city of Juliaca). Her shop is very popular because her customers know that the meat that she sells is very high quality and that they are buying something delicious to eat. This quality is due to the fact that Margarita is very mindful when choosing the meat that she sells.

What she likes most about her job is talking with her customers. She has been in this line of work for 16 years and considers the most difficult part to be having to stay at her sales stall all day without being able to leave. In the future she hopes that her business will grow and bring her a higher income.

This is the Margarita's 3rd loan with MFP (Microfinanzas Prisma, a Kiva partner), and she is prepared to make all her payments on time because she does not want to jeopardize the other members of her communal bank, where she is very well-liked for the happiness she brings to the group. With the 1000 Peruvian soles (US$350) she is requesting, Margarita will buy more meat in order to increase the quantity that she normally sells.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy meat for butcher shop

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria tiene 41 años, es una mujer muy amable y sencilla, vive en una habitación alquilada y lo que más desea es mejorar su calidad de vida. Su negocio es el lavado de ropa, desde muy joven se vio en la necesidad de trabajar y vio que lavar ropa para otras personas era una actividad que le daba los ingresos que necesitaban y actualmente ella ha mejorado su calidad de vida con esta actividad y ya cuenta con algunas comodidades. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que ella es su propio jefe y puede disponer de su tiempo, lleva 10 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que lavar cuando hace frió, ya que el agua es muy helada y muchas veces le ha causado resfriados muy fuertes. Para el futuro espera tener un negocio más estable, una bodega es lo que más le llama la atención.
Maria se encuentra en su cuarto préstamo con MFP, ha sido muy puntual en sus primeros créditos y espera serlo ahora también, en su banco comunal es muy responsable con los acuerdos a los que llegan en sus reuniones. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevos lavadores y baldes, ya que los que usaba están muy desgastados.
texts.en:
Maria is 41 years old and lives in a rented home. She is a very kind and modest woman who desires most to improve her quality of life. Maria washes clothes, which is something she has done since she was very young because she needed to work. Washing clothes for other people was an activity in which she could earn money. She has been able to improve her living conditions and buy a few items to make life more comfortable. What she likes most about her work is being her own boss and managing her own time. Maria has been doing this type of work for 10 years and the most difficult part is having to do laundry in cold weather because the water is freezing and she has become ill on several occasions. In the future, she hopes to have a more stable business. Opening a grocery store is at the top of her list.

Maria is taking her fourth loan with MFP. She has been very punctual with her previous loans and hopes to do the same again with this loan. She is very responsible in the discussions that are held at her Communal Bank meetings. With her loan of 1000 soles, Maria will buy new scrubbers and buckets because her existing equipment is well worn.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for washing clothes

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan S. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan De Oro City. She is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Susan owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Susan is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Susan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria tiene 42 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a sus 2 hijos: Guillermo de 14 y Daysi de 16 años, quienes son el motivo principal de todos sus esfuerzos. La carretilla de golosinas de Maria está ubicada en el Parque Bolognesi (parque importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), es muy concurrida por sus clientes, ya que está muy bien ubicada y ella es muy conocida por su buen humor y carisma, lo cual ha hecho que sus ventas le den los ingresos que necesita. Lo que más le gusta a Maria de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes y hacerlos reír, lleva 18 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que vender bajo los fuertes rayos solares de la mañana. Por ello, para el futuro anhela tener una tienda de golosinas donde pueda vender con más comodidad.
Este es el sétimo préstamo de Maria con MFP y está dispuesta a pagarlo a tiempo, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida por el resto de sus compañeras. Con los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más golosinas para implementar mejor los productos que ofrece en su carretilla.
texts.en:
Maria is 42 years old and a very hardworking woman. She lives at home with her two children, Guillermo (age 14) and Daysi (age 16). They are the main reason for everything she does. Maria operates a pushcart from which she sells candy at Bolognesi Park (a large park in the city of Juliaca). She is well-known among her customers for her good humor and charisma, as well as for being in a good location. Maria says she enjoys talking with her customers and making them laugh. She has been in business for 18 years and the most difficult part is working under the strong rays of the sun in the mornings. In the future, she hopes to open her own candy store where she can sell her products more comfortably.

This is Maria’s seventh loan with MFP. She is willing to make her payments on time because she does not want to cause problems for the other members of her Communal Bank. She has a great deal of admiration for her fellow members. With her loan of 2000 soles, she will buy more candy so that she can improve the selection of products that she offers from her cart.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her supply of candy

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria tiene 18 años, es una jovencita muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en la casa de sus padres y tiene muchas ganas de sobresalir en la vida. Aunque es muy joven, no quiere ser una carga para sus padres, es por eso que ha decidido trabajar en la empresa familiar y ganar su propio dinero. Ella trabaja confeccionando zapatos junto a sus padres y hermanos, los cuales luego lleva a vender en el puesto que tienen en el mercado San José (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca). Lo que más le gusta a Maria de su trabajo es diseñar nuevos modelos de zapatos. Lleva 2 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es trasladar los zapatos hasta su puesto de venta porque por la cantidad que lleva es una carga pesada. Para el futuro anhela tener su propia empresa de calzado, con la cual pueda ganar su dinero y formar una familia.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Maria con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y está dispuesta a hacerlo. En su banco comunal es una socia muy respetada por la responsabilidad que demuestra. Con los mil doscientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevos materiales para confeccionar más zapatos.

loans.use: Compra de materiales para elaborar zapatos

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva I. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan De Oro City. She is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Eva owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Eva has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Eva joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Eva is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Eva from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sindy

texts.es:
Sindy tiene 20 años, es una joven alegre y sencilla, vive en la casa de sus padres y lo que más desea es sobresalir en la vida. El puesto de artesanías de Sindy está ubicado en el Parque Bolognesi (parque importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), su puesto es uno de los más llamativos debido a las artesanías tan bonitas que elabora y vende, además se puede encontrar de todo; desde llaveros, hasta prendas tejidas a mano. Lo que más le gusta a Sindy de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes, lleva 3 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta. Para el futuro espera tener una tienda más grande donde pueda brindar a sus clientes una mayor comodidad.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Sindy con MFP y está muy feliz de la nueva oportunidad de crédito. En su banco comunal es una socia muy solidaria con el resto de sus compañeras. Con los mil doscientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más material para elaborar sus artesanías y así implementar mejor su stock.
texts.en:
Sindy is a lively and easygoing 20-year-old who lives at home with her parents. What she wants most is to excel in life. Sindy's crafts booth is located in Bolognesi Park (a major park in the city of Juliaca) and is one of the most eye-catching due to the beautiful crafts that she makes and sells. One can find a bit of everything at the booth, from keychains to garments woven by hand.

What Sindy likes the most about her job is talking with customers. She has been in this line of work for 3 years and considers the most difficult thing to be having to stay all day in her sales booth. In the future Sindy hopes to have a bigger store where she can bring her customers greater comfort and convenience.

This is Sindy's third loan with MFP (Microfinanzas Prisma, a Kiva Field partner), and she is very happy to have this new opportunity for a loan. In her communal bank she is a very supportive member with the rest of her business partners. With the 1200 Peruvivan soles (US$425), she will buy more materials to make her crafts so she can increase her stock.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy materials to make crafts

loans.name: Violeta

texts.es: Violeta tiene 20 años, es una joven muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en la casa de sus padres, a quienes desea ayudar en los gastos del hogar y darles una vejez tranquila. Los días de Violeta son muy agitados, ya que ella tiene un restaurante muy concurrido y tiene que estar corriendo de un lado a otro para atender a todos sus clientes. Sus comidas son muy halagadas por los comensales, ya que tiene una muy buena sazón y aunque es muy joven todavía, siente que ha perdido años de trabajo. Lo que más le gusta de su negocio es cocinar y lo hace con mucha alegría, lleva 2 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que atender ella sola a todos sus clientes. Para el futuro espera que su negocio crezca y se convierta en uno de los restaurantes más conocidos de la ciudad de Juliaca. Este es el tercer préstamo de Violeta con MFP y sabe que tiene que pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, en su banco comunal es muy alegre y siempre está al tanto de todos los acuerdos que tienen entre socias. Con los setecientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevas ollas, platos y cubiertos, ya que los que usa actualmente están muy gastados.
texts.en:
Violeta is 20 years old and is a very cheerful and hardworking young woman. She lives in her parents' house, and she wants to help them with household expenses and make it possible for them to take it easy in their old age. Violeta's days are very busy, since she has a popular restaurant and she has to run around waiting on all of her customers. Her meals are highly regarded by the diners, because she's a good cook and, even though she is still young, she feels that she has lost years of work. What she likes most about her business is cooking, which does very gladly. She's been doing this for 2 years and she considers the most difficult part to be having to wait on the customers all by herself. In the future, she hopes that her business will grow and become one of the most well-known restaurants in the city of Juliaca. This is Violeta's third loan with MFP and she knows that she has to make her payments on time. She is very happy with her communal bank and is always up-to-date with all the agreements among its members. With the 700 nuevos soles requested, she will buy new pots, plates and silverware, since the ones she currently uses are wearing out.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy utensils for her restaurant

loans.name: Carmencita

texts.en:
Carmencita P. is from the village of Punta Sulong. She is 52 years old. Carmencita is married. To make a living, Carmencita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Carmencita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Carmencita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmencita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from PMPC. Carmencita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Carmencita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Norberta

texts.en:
Norberta P. is from the village of Bigaan. She is 54 years old. Norberta is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Norberta owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing transportation services to local community members. Norberta has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Norberta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norberta has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Norberta is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Norberta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a motorcycle for transport.

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg M. is 54 years old and lives with her two children in an apartment in the Bayanzurkh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter is currently studying for her master's degree at the Mongolian Science and Technology University and her son drives a taxi in the city.

Altantsetseg  operates a women's clothing  and lingerie retail business from a stall at a local clothing market. She sells a variety of different clothing items and accessories and her wide product selection attracts many customers. Altantsetseg started her women's clothing business in 2000 selling only general women's clothing items. After finding success and achieving stable business operations, she expanded her product line to include lingerie and clothing accessories. This product expansion has proved to be a very profitable decision. Today, her working capital exceeds 2,700,000 tugrugs and she has daily average profits of 60,000 tugrugs.

Altantsetseg is a very open-minded and sociable woman and is well known by her customers. For the future, she says, "I would like to have another stall to expand my business and increase my sales". She is requesting a  4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more women's clothing items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more women's clothing items.

loans.name: Sosorburam

texts.en: Sosorburam D. lives with her two grandchildren in Uvukhangai province in central Mongolia. They all live together in her ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home. She provides for both of her grandchildren, including paying tuition for her grandson. He currently attends a university in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. D. operates a cosmetic trading business in her town. She sells a variety of cosmetic products that are imported from China, Korea and Japan. Her children live and work in Japan and help deliver some of the products to her. D. started her cosmetic trading business in 2007 by renting a stall at the local market. She travels once or twice a month to Ulaanbaatar  to purchase products to sell. For the future, D. hopes to grow her business further so she can continue to provide for her grandson's education. She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase more cosmetics for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics

loans.name: Rodel

texts.en:
Rodel I. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de oro City. He is 35 years old and single. To make a living, Rodel works as foreman at a construction site, and at the same time he raises pigs for sale as his additional source of income. Rodel has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately $110 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rodel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Rodel is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services he provides. This will be his second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Dugarjav

texts.en: Dugarjav N. is 58 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Her husband, Shunkhlai, works as a carpenter and makes wooden products and some iron crafts. Her oldest daughter currently attends a university and her youngest son is a high school student. N. owns and operates a clothing production business in her town. She designs and produces a wide variety of traditional Mongolian clothing items. Her specialty is producing "deels", which are  traditional Mongolian coats. N. started her clothing production business in 1993 and has been in stable operation since. Her business is very popular in her community and she has built a positive reputation among her customers. She graduated as a dressmaker in 1975 and made dresses at a large indoor services market until 1993. For the future, N. hopes to further grow her business and use her earnings to finish building a home for her son. She is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan to purchase more fabrics and materials for her traditional Mongolian clothing business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and materials

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth D. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 30 years old and married with one school-age child. To make a living, Maribeth sells personal home products like soap and bathroom cleanser in her  community. Maribeth has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $87 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maribeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Maribeth is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tserendejid

texts.en:
M. Tserendejid is 37 years old and lives with her parents and two children in the Bayanzurkh district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. They all live together in her parents' home, which they rent. She currently supports her son and daughter, both of whom are college students.

Tserendejid operates a women's retail lingerie business at a large retail trading center in the city. She started her business in 2005 with the help of her husband. The two traveled together between Ulaanbaatar and Irkutsk, Russia, to purchase clothing products for the business. Tserendejid used to sell a variety of clothing items before her husband passed away in 2008, but has sold only lingerie since.

Over the years, Tserendejid has gained a great deal of business experience and has improved her business by continually expanding her product line. She attributes her success to her good taste and ability to select stylish and quality products for her customers. For the future, Tserendejid hopes to continue to improve her business and will use future earnings to move her family to their own home. She says, "I just want to have a home where my children and I can be comfortable." She is requesting a 770,000 tugrug loan to buy more lingerie for her business.

loans.use: To buy more lingerie to sell

loans.name: Romel

texts.en:
Romel B. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 27 years old and single. To make a living, Romel provides services as a construction worker. Romel has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately $87 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Romel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand the services he provides. Romel is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide his service. This will be his second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide his services

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 45 years old and married with five children between the ages of 14 and 20. Her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Sylvia resides in a one-room rented house with five other people. There is no electricity and piped water in the home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala in the Ndeeba Mpomba zone.

Rehema works seven days a week. She buys cassava potatoes and maize where she works so she doesn’t incur extra transportation costs to and from shopping. She doesn’t pay rent on a market stall because she sells from her home. She sells to all categories of people.

Sylvia has been in this business for twenty years and with MCDT for six, now servicing her fifteenth loan and working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more cassava potatoes and maize to sell. Rehema would like to see her business grow so she could start buying products to sell directly from farmers.

loans.use: To buy more cassava potatoes and maize

loans.name: Sangita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sangita B. has a grocery store in the Town of Chetrapati. She opened her store a few years ago and sells several kinds of groceries. She opened her store to improve her family's standard of living. Due to a lack of money she cannot upgrade her store, so she is requesting a Rs 20000 loan to buy various grocery goods.

Mrs. Sangita B. lives with her husband and one son. Her husband has no work so the condition of her family is miserable.

loans.use: To buy a variety of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Jing

texts.en:
Jing E. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old and married with one small child (see picture). To make a living, Jing has a bread delivery business. She buys a variety of bread products and sells them in the local community. Jing is just starting this business.

In 2008, Jing joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jing has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Jing is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Bishnu

texts.en:
Bishnu D. is a farmer in the village of Chapagaun. Chapagaun is one of the developing villages of the Lalitpur district and most of the people in this village are engaged in agricultural farming. She grows green vegetables on her land and sells them in the local market both morning and evening. Mostly she grows seasonal vegetables. She is requesting a Rs 25000 loan to buys seeds and fertilizers for her vegetable farm.

Bishnu D. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband is a laborer in house construction work. She has one son and one daughter. Her daughter is studying in grade five and her son is in pre-school.

loans.use: To buys seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en:
Kasifa is 27 years-old and married with three children, aged four and nine years, who attend school. She also takes care of additional family members. Kasifa lives in a rented one-roomed house with five other people. There is no electricity or piped water in the house. The family eats three meals per day.

Kasifa lives and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Ndeeba Mpomba zone. She works seven days-a-week, buying tomatoes and other fruits from the market to avoid transport costs. She doesn’t pay rent but pays daily market dues of 700 UGX a day .She sells to all types of people, and has been in this business for six years, and with MCDT for seven. This is her fourteenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more tomatoes, cabbages, and carrots. Kasifa aspires to see her business grow bigger so that she can start buying directly from farmers.

loans.use: to buy more tomatoes, cabbages, and carrots

loans.name: Inocencia

texts.en:
Inocencia M. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Inocencia has run her business for almost two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Inocencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Inocencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product range. Inocencia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP to expand her range further. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Inocencia from HSPFI.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product range

loans.name: Tarimai

texts.en: Mrs. Tarimai D. is a farmer in the village of Chappagaun. Both Mrs. D. and Mr. D. are engaged in agricultural farming. They grow green and seasonal vegetables on their land. They sell their vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening, daily. Now Mrs. D. is requesting a Rs 25000 loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for agricultural work.

loans.use: To buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy C. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 20 years old. Daisy is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Daisy owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for her business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Daisy has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Daisy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Daisy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita C. lives in Tangal, Lalitpur. Tangal is one of the busiest bazaars in Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in making kitchen utensils.

Rita is a grocery shopkeeper in the town of Tangal. She opened her grocery store a few years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. She sells rice, maize, snacks, etc., in her shop. She is now requesting a Rs 20000 loan to invest in her shop to attract more new customers.

Rita C. lives with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Kiran C., is engaged in his own small business. Her older son is in pre-primary school and her younger son is just 3 months old.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah N. is a 35 year old lady who is married to John Waweru and has eight school going children. Hannah has been selling fuel in small quanities in Naivasha town for the last six years.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and she is now applying for her second loan after servicing her first loan well. With the first loan she bought more tanks so that she could increase her storing capacity and with this second loan, she plans to buy more fuel for sale to boost her business.

In future, Hannah has a dream of opening up a mini petrol station that will not only serve residents of Naivasha town but also people who pass through Naivasha going to various destinations.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more petrol for sale.

loans.name: Dharma Shova

texts.en:
Dharma Shova B. is the cosmetic shopkeeper in the town of Tangal. She opens her cosmetic shop two months ago to uplift the living standard of her family. In her shop she sells different types of cosmetic goods such as make-up tools, lipsticks, cream powers etc. In Nepal September is the month of big festivals. So the demands of cosmetic goods are very high in this month. So Mrs. B.  is requesting for Rs 20000.00 loan to buys different types of cosmetic goods to meet the demand of the customers.
Mrs. B. lives in a joint family with her husband, father-in-law , mother-in-law and two brother-in-laws

loans.use: to buys cosmetics goods

loans.name: Nabunjo Sylvia Group

texts.en:
Sylvia is 25 and married with three children aged between 4 and 7 years. All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members as well. Sylvia resides in and rents a two roomed house where she is staying with four people. There is electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala in Mulago. 

Sylvia works seven days a week. She buys her second hand clothing from Owino market and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  She pays monthly rent of 5000/=.  She sells to all categories of people, in both retail and whole sale. Sylvia has been in this business for three years, with MCDT for six months and now servicing her second loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more second hand clothing. Sylvia is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to start importing clothing directly.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothing

loans.name: Francis Kimani

texts.en: Francis Kimani is married to Joyce who is a farmer and they have two children: Jonathan (30 years old) and Monicah (25 years old). Francis has been selling water for 14 years and his other sources of income are farming and rental houses which he had put up. His area of business is densely populated and thus he has a ready market for his water and rental houses. Francis was introduced to KADET by existing group members. He has applied for a loan which he will use to buy new iron sheets so that he can repair his rental houses. With the extra profits, Francis intends to acquire two plastic tanks for water storage. Francis aspires to expand his businesses and own an estate. He describes himself as hardworking and on his way to achieving his goals. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy new iron sheets to repair his rental houses

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard has been operating his motorcycle business in Naivasha town for the last three years. He is 28 years old and married to Margaret Njeri and they have two school-going children. Bernard was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan with the organization and he's planning to use the proceeds to repair and service his motorbike. In future Bernard plans to grow in the transportation business, owning his own fleet of taxis. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle

loans.name: David

texts.en: David has been rearing sheep for sale for one year now in Naivasha town and has managed to increase the number of his sheep to forty. He is 47 years old and married to Lucy Njeri and they have three school-going children. David was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. With the proceeds of this loan he plans to buy medicine for his sheep. David still sees himself in his livestock business in the near future and he wants to have a big farm where he will be rearing and selling sheep wholesale, not just in Naivasha town alone but also in other major towns near Naivasha, e.g, Nairobi and Nakuru towns. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy medicine for his sheep

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick M. has been rearing poultry for the last seven years in Naivasha town. His poultry business includes both meat and egg sales. He is 29 years old and married to Agnes Kwambuka and they have one school-going child. Patrick was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan and he plans to buy feed for his chickens with the proceeds. In future he hopes to get tenders to supply hotels with his chicken meat and eggs. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy feed for his chickens

loans.name: Kisan Kumari

texts.en:
Kisan Kumari R. is the resident of Tikhidewol. Tikhidewol is located in Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in small business. Mrs. Kisan Kumari R. lives in single family with her husband and one son. Her son is studying in pre-primary school.
Both Mrs. and Mr. R. are engaged in tailoring work. Tailoring is their traditional work. They learn tailoring work from their forefathers. They make different types of clothes for both ladies and dresses. Especially they make pants and shirts for gents and Kurta Sulwar, Blouse, Makhshi, for ladies.
Now Mrs. R. is requesting for Rs 10000.00 loan to buy raw materials for tailoring work.

loans.use: to buys raw materials for her work

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 46 years old and married with four children aged between 4 and 19 years, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Margaret resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she lives with five people. There is no electricity or piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Margaret resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala in Ndeeba Mpomba zone. She works seven days a week. She buys her sacks of charcoal from suppliers who get them from villages and so doesn’t incur extra transport costs to and from shopping. She doesn’t pay rent but pays daily market dues of 700/= a day. She sells to all categories of people both in retail and wholesale.

Margaret has been in this business for eighteen years and with MCDT for seven. She is servicing her fourteenth loan working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal.

Margaret is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to start going to villages herself.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Ruwa

texts.en:
Ruwa K. is a resident of Thikedewal. She and her husband, Mr. Lal Bahadur K., are engaged in selling green vegetables. They buy the vegetables from Kalimati market and sell them daily in the local market in the morning and evening. They fulfill all the requirement of their family with the income from selling vegetables.

Ruwa K. and her husband have three children: two daughters and one son. Their daughters are studying in grade 5 and 4 and their son is studying in grade 1.

loans.use: To buy green vegetables to sell

loans.name: Loice Jebiwott

texts.en: Loice is married to Simington Kiptoo and they have been blessed with five children. Loice’s fruits and vegetables banda business is located in Chembulet centre. Loice was introduced to KADET by other members in the Burar Soyet Group who are also KADET clients. She has applied for a loan which she intends to use to add more stock to her vegetable business which includes tomatoes, onions, kale and bananas. In future, Loice intends to expand her business by opening other branches elsewhere within and outside the Keiyo Districts. Her dream is to own her own car. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more stock to her vegetable kiosk

loans.name: Aballo

texts.en:
Aballo C. is currently in the business of selling beer at home  and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell.  Aballo is 35 years old and is Married with a husband that is a security guard. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is a 33 married with four children aged between 4 and 10 years. Her children go to school .She takes care of additional family members. Juliet resides and rents a three roomed house where she is staying with five people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Mengo Mackay Kosovo zone. Juliet works seven days a week. She buys her chicken feeds from Owino Market and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  She doesn’t pay rent as she works from her home.She sells to all categories of people both on retail and whole sale Juliet has been in this business for 18 years and with MCDT for seven, servicing her fourteenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feeds and chicks l. Juliet is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning 800 chicken .

loans.use: to buy more chicken feeds and chicks

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en: Nelson M. has been transporting his clients through the famous bodaboda transport around Naivasha town for the last two years. Bodaboda is where one uses his bicycle for transporting people around a town. The bicycle is fitted with a tailor-made seat where clients sit and the bike rider cycles them to their intended destination. Nelson is 22 years old and still single. Nelson was introduced to KADET by his friend. He has applied for a loan which he wants to use to buy a motorbike and upgrade from the bicycle that he uses. In the near future, Nelson hopes to own a pick-up truck which he will use to move people’s goods to and from the main market in Naivasha town. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Asue

texts.en: Asue R. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to purchase dried fish and onions to sell. Asue is 29 years old and is widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy dried fish and onions to sell

loans.name: Kamala

texts.en:
Mrs. Kamala R. lives in Thikedewal, Lalitpur. She has one son and three daughters. Her son is in grade 12, her two older daughters are studying for a BBS (Bachelor in Business Studies) degree and her youngest daughter is in grade 7. A few years ago, her husband, Bal Ram R., died. She now has sole responsibility for her four children.

Mrs. R. makes different types of artificial flower decorations and sells her flower decorations in the local flower shop. She trained for one month at the flower training institution.

Mrs. R. is requesting a loan of Rs 15,000 to buy materials for her work.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Bishnu Kumari

texts.en:
Bishuna Kumari R., a resident of Tikhidewal, lives in a single family home with her husband and one son. Her husband, Mr. Hukum Singh Gurung, is a plumber. Her son is studying in grade 2.

Mrs. R. is a shopkeeper in the town of Tikhidewal. She opened her food shop few months ago to strengthen the economic conditions of her family. She sells Nepali food in her shop. She also serve tea and coffee to her customers.

Because this month is in the festivals season in Nepal, the demand for the foods are increasing rapidly. So, Mrs. R. is requesting for the loan of Rs 15000.00 to buy food materials to meet the increasing demand of her customers.

loans.use: to buys food materials for her shop

loans.name: James

texts.en: James W. has been making furniture in Naivasha town for the last eleven years. He is 50 years old and married to Pauline Wanjiku and they have two school-going children. James heard about KADET through the marketing promotions done by the company staff. This will be his second loan with the organization and he plans to buy more timber as material for his business. He paid off his first loan well and he used that money to buy new tools for his trade to replace the older ones. James intends to continue growing the size of his workshop and to employ someone who will help him in carpentry as his production and number of orders increase. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more timber for his business

loans.name: Franise

texts.en:
Franise M. is currently in the business of selling bread and phaste and is requesting a loan to open up a bakery. Franise is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a teacher. She has 3 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a bakery

loans.name: Dedan

texts.en:
Dedan W. is 26 years old and has been selling secondhand clothes in Naivasha (about 50 miles northwest of Nairobi) for the last three years. He was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his second loan, and he plans to buy more secondhand clothes to sell. He paid off his first loan on time and used his profits to increase his stock.

Currently Dedan operates his business out in the open air, but in the future he plans to move to a more permanent place.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET at: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Nita

texts.en:
Mrs. Nita L. lives in Tikathali in the Lalitpur district of Nepal. Nita lives with her husband, brother-in-law and sister-in-law. Both her brother-in-law and sister-in-law are studying in secondary school.

Mrs. and Mr. L. opened a shop four years ago from which they sell gas and gas stoves. She is requesting a loan of 15000 NPR to add some gas cylinders to their shop to meet the increasing demands of their customers.

Nita wants to upgrade her family’s standard of living with all profits resulting from this loan.

loans.use: To stock gas cylinders in her shop

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and one son in Thecho, Lalitpur. Thecho Mrs. Laxmi M. Live in a sing family with her husband and two sons in Thecho. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming.


Both Mrs. M. and her husband Cheri Babu M. are engaged in wood craft work. They make different types of wood craft according to the orders they receive. 



Now Mrs. M. is requesting a loan in the amount of Rs 25000.00 loan to buy timbers and tools for their woodcraft work. Mrs. M. is saving her income to provide a good education for her sons because the educational cost is very high in Nepal.

loans.use: to buys timbers and tools

loans.name: Kojo

texts.en:
J. is 29 years old and married; her husband is a driver. She has four children who all go to school. 

J. is currently in the business of selling beer from her home in Southern Sudan. She is requesting a loan to open a bar at a nearby market. With the extra profits resulting from her loan, she hopes to be able to build her own distillery.  

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, targeted towards war refugees returning to their native home, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar at a nearby market

loans.name: Susan Jemeli

texts.en:
Susan Jemeli is 24 years and is blessed with two children.Her clothing business is located in Chembulet Centre and her clients are residents of Chembulet.

She was introduced to KADET by a current KADET member.

With the loan Susan intends to use  to add more stock which includes trousers,skirts and dresses for women.In future she would like to continue with more clothing businesses and also expand by opening another branch in Chepkinaiyo.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more clothing stock for both adult and children.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita G. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives with her mother-in-law, her husband and a daughter. Her daughter is in primary school. Her husband's name is Radesh G. and he opened his computer institute 7 years ago, where he teaches basic computer and graphic design courses. He has four computers at his institute, but that is not enough to meet the demands of the students. He wants to buy another computer, but due to lack of funds he cannot afford it. So, his wife is requesting her fifth loan to buy another computer to help her husband. This will also help to provide a better income for her family, and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buys computers

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has operated her general shop, selling household goods in Naivasha town, for the last one year. She is married to David Karanja and has four children. Her firstborn has already graduated from school while the other three are still school-going.

Elizabeth was introduced to KADET by her friend. This will be her second loan with which she plans to add more stock to her business. She paid off her first loan well, which she used in opening her shop. And with this new loan she plans to add more stock in her retails shop.

In the near future Elizabeth plans to own a bigger shop in a building that she will put up.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website:  www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more stock for her business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane E. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and green vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell.  Jane is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peassnt. She has no children at all.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motor boat for fishing BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Barikissou

texts.fr: Barikissou est mariée et mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Barikissou vit avec sa famille et supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille. Barikissou vend des glacières, ustensiles de cuisine, bassines et sacs de sortie pour femme. C’est au Nigeria, État voisin du Bénin que Barikissou va faire ses achats et revient au Bénin pour les livrer à ses clients qui ont fait la demande. C’est depuis huit ans que Barikissou est dans cette activité et elle a déjà eu deux prêts d’ALIDé pour cette activité. Dans l’optique de mieux développer son activité, Barikissou sollicite encore un troisième crédit d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
Barikissou is married and the mother of four children, all in school. Barikissou lives with her family, she and her husband provide for the family expenses. Barikissou sells ice coolers, kitchen utensils, basins and women purses.

Barikissou makes her purchases in Nigeria, a neighboring state of Bénin. She makes deliveries to customers who request it . Barikissou has been in this business for eight years, she has already received two loans from Alidé for this activity. In order to better develop her business, she is asking for a third loan from Alidé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ice coolers, shoes and purses

loans.name: Bedan

texts.en:
Bedan has operated his butcher shop in Naivasha town for the last 2 years.  He is 30 years old and married to Naomi Wambui, they have 5 school going children.

He was intoroduced to KADET by his friend.  He paid his first loan well which he used to renovate his butcher shop with.  He is now applying for the second loan and he plans to buy sheep to rear so that by December the holiday season, he will slaughter and sell the meat.  This will give him a bigger profit compared to buying the meat for sale during that time bescause the prices will have gone up.

In future he still plans to continue with the butcher shop and enlarge it and even move to the town center.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy sheep for rearing which he will later slaughter for sale

loans.name: Bina

texts.en:
Mrs. Bina M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single (ie. not extended) family with her husband Chakra and five daughters. Her husband is a farmer and works on his own land. All five daughters are now studying. 

Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop two years ago to raise the living standard of her family. Their financial condition is not good, so they can't provide better education for their daughters, as the cost of education is very high in Nepal. To overcome this problem, Mrs. M. opened her grocery shop. 

Due to a lack of capital, she can't keep stocks of grocery items for her shop. She is asking for her second loan of Rs20000.00 to buy goods like rice, utensils, noodles, etc. She plans to spend her income to provide better education for their daughters and wishes to help her husband to upgrade the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: to buys grocery goods

loans.name: Bebina

texts.en: Bebina O., 54 years old, lives in a poor community in Parola, Binondo, Manila. Her husband is a carpenter and they have five children. Bebina's hands are always full of things to do every day. She has a general store and a small food station where she cooks food and sells it to customers. She is making P21,000 a month in gross revenues and uses her profits to sustain daily family needs. Bebina joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative so she applied for a new loan in the amount of P34,000 as additional capital for the continued growth of her business. She will restock on non-perishable grocery items to sell at her store. Bebina wishes to see her store to grow like a mini-mart or a supermarket someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Ujima

texts.en: Ujima P. is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Ujima is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has three children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah B., 30, is a successful micro-entrepreneur. She lives in and does business in BASECO Compound, Port Area, Manila – a shantytown on the coast of the metropolis. Her husband, Renato, 35, works as a security personnel. They have two school-aged kids.

Leah owns a general store located at the heart of a flea market in the community where she sells charcoal and coconuts. When customers buy coconuts, her store offers customers a value-added service: to grate their coconut for a minimal fee. She has a mechanical grater that does the job fast and efficiently. Leah earns more than P45,000 a month. She saves her profits. She feels a sense of economic security every time she looks at the growing figures in her savings passbook.

Leah has been hearing a lot of good things about the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative but became a member only last year. She is about to finish repaying her previous loan with the cooperative. She applied for a new loan in the amount of P24,000 as additional capital for the continuity of her business. She is now on her 6th loan. 

Leah dreams of having a bakery and a grocery store. She also wishes to have a large house with a swimming pool beside it.


About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Francis Jesee Gachui

texts.en:
Francis N. is single and resides within Nairobi.

He has been running a food retail business for four years. His business is in a general public market which has many buyers and sellers and his customers are not specific but the quality of the tomatoes and onions determines the customers.

WIth no previous loan from another institution, he was introduced to KADET through existing group members. He has applied for a loan which he will use to get more stock and get into new markets and with the extra profits the client intends to build rental houses in an acquired plot.

The client aspires to become a wholesale supplier of tomatoes, onions and other groceries to the retailers as he believes he is determined focused and hardworking.

loans.name: Sêlomè Rosalie

texts.fr: ABAÏ Sêlomè Rosalie est née le 30 Décembre 1961 à Zangnanado au Sud du Bénin et réside depuis sept ans à Cocotomey non loin de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUNKANLIN Rock un retraité de "l’hotel Croix du Sud", Sêlomè Rosalie est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Grâce aux revenus tirés des produits de ses ventes, Sêlomè Rosalie vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Sêlomè Rosalie vend des condiments et divers articles (boîtes de conserve, lait, savons, pâtes alimentaires, riz, etc.) à son domicile à Cocotomey. Sêlomè Rosalie achète ses différents produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Avec cinq ans d’expérience dans ce domaine, Sêlomè Rosalie est à son deuxième crédit à ALIDé. Le premier crédit a eu pour impact une augmentation de son chiffre d’affaire. En sollicitant à nouveau un crédit, Sêlomè Rosalie ambitionne accroître davantage son activité.
texts.en:
ABAÏ Sêlomè Rosalie was born on December 30, 1961 in Zangnanado in southern Benin.  She has been residing for seven years in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  She is married to HOUNKANLIN Rock, a retiree of the Hotel Croix du Sud, and is the mother of three children, who are all in school.  Thanks to the revenues derived from her sales, Sêlomè Rosalie comes to her husband's aid to meet family expenses. Sêlomè Rosalie sells condiments and various goods (canned food, milk, soaps, pasta, rice, etc.) out of her home in Cocotomey.  She purchases her different goods at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin.  With five years of experience in this domain, she is on her second ALIDé loan.  The impact of her first load was to increase her sales figures.  In requesting a new loan, she has the ambition of growing her business further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy three baskets of tomatoes, five boxes of canned milk, and two 50-kg sacks of rice

texts.en:
Paul K. has been running his Agrovet business in Naivasha town for three years now. He attributes the success of his business to his local community, which consists of many farmers. Paul is 42 years old and married to Ruth Nyambura; they have a pair of twin sons who attend secondary school fifty miles from Naivasha town.

Paul was introduced to KADET by his friend. He is in repayment for his first loan and has applied for the education loan, which KADET offers to existing clients at zero percent interest. Paul plans to use the loans to pay academic fees for his sons' educations.

His future business plan is to grow his business and be a major supplier in Naivasha town, conducting both retail and bulk sales.

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr: A. Pierrette est née en 1970 à Sakété, dans la commune de l’Ouémé au Sud du Bénin. Mariée à FALOLOU Ignace, Pierrette est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés et deux enfants sont à sa charge. Pierrette réside depuis deux ans à Cocotomey non loin de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par son mari Ignace. Pierrette achète depuis trois ans des tissus et des chaussures à Lomé, pays voisin du Bénin, qu’elle vend à Cocotomey. Pour renforcer son fonds de roulement et accroître son activité, Pierrette sollicite auprès de ALIDé, l’obtention d’un crédit.
texts.en:
A. Pierrette was born in 1970 in Sakété, in the community of Ouémé in southern Benin.  She is married to FALOLOU Ignace and is the mother of four children, who are all in school, and two children are in her care.  Pierrette has been residing for two years in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  Family expenses are covered by her husband, Ignace.  For three years, Pierrette has been purchasing cloth and shoes in Lomé, the capital of Togo, a country neighboring Benin.  She sells these goods in Cocotomey.  To bolster her working capital and to grow her business, she's requesting a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth and shoes

Hannah is a single mother aged 49 years old. She has two children Peter Muigai and Grace wanjiku aged 28 years and 20 years respecively.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou R. is 51 years old and she owns a store where she sells mobile phones accessories. She lives and does business in Parola Compound, Binondo, Manila – a shanty town at the edge of the city coastlines. Her husband Menardo, age 48, repairs shoes and umbrellas for a living. Their two children are both in school. The eldest child is currently enrolled in college and the other child is in high school.

Marilou has been operating different businesses for more than two decades, but she opened her mobile phone store just four years age. She earns a net income of P16,000.00 a month. Much of her profits go to her children's education, while others are budgeted for their daily basic needs.

She is now studying the possibility of getting into new business ventures. She hopes that the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative will help her with her study. 

Marilou has applied for a new loan of P22,000, which she will use as additional capital for her mobile phones accessories business.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.
