loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en:
Uranchimeg T. lives with her husband and three grown-up children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her eldest son is 28-year-old and drives a private cab in the city. Her 25-year-old daughter stays home and takes care of the family. Her youngest son is 24-year-old and a student at a local university called “Guur."

Uranchimeg sells sunglasses and windows insulation materials at the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor black market in Ulaanbaatar. She says that by selling these products, sunglasses and insulation materials, she hedges the seasonal income fluctuation in her business. Sunglasses sell well during the warm season, whereas the windows insulation materials are sold during cold seasons.

Her eldest son helps with her business and brings products for her business. Since the start in 1999, she has been doing well in the business and her capital has increased from 300,000 MNT to 1,000,000 MNT. She says she aims to make enough profit to pay for her youngest son's tuition. She requests a loan to purchase more windows insulation as the cold season approaches in Mongolia.

loans.use: Purchase  insulation materials.

loans.name: Uch

texts.en: A widow mother lives with her two adults daughters whom are the garment workers, C., 52, raises her living situation by selling general daily accessories such as cook ingredients, plastic, child cake, charcoal, and so on. She could earn up to $3.00 per day. She has a motor for her business transportation because she goes to the center market once a week looking for materials or any elements that would be benefits her income to be sold at her store. She is recently looking for a loan to invest in her selling of her general store.

loans.use: to invest in her selling of her general store.

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
Venus Engarcia is from Aguada, Ozamiz City. She is 49 years old, separated with two adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a boarding house. Most of her boarders are students. She has been in this business for 10 years and earns approximately 10,000.00 PHP a month.

In May 2009, she joined PMPC to access financial services and to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC in the amount of 5,000.00 PHP with a good record of repayment. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000.00 PHP which will be used to buy building materials to improve her boarding house and make it more presentable. Venus plans to use the additional revenue to sustain her everyday expenses.

loans.use: Buy building materials for her boarding house.

loans.name: Mrs. Sopheap Long Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap L. is a village bank president who has been selected by the ten clients in Chrouy village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sopheap L. is fruit seller in the local market. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy different kinds of fruit to re-sell in her current business. Her husband, Mr. Ngaet Bo, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn for living. Mrs. Sopheap L. is 38 years old and the mother of four children three of who are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because they are at the age of 5 years old. 

Eight members in this village bank loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy different kinds of fruit to re-sell in her current business.

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en: Leonisa O. is a 50-year-old hardworking mother who dreams of helping her husband earn a living for their family to provide a better future for her children. She is married and blessed with four young adult children ranging in age from 18 to 25 years old. The family lives in the village of Rogie, Bi-ao, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. Because of her strong determination to help her family, Leonisa started selling agricultural products in her community. Even though it only earned her a small income, she was happy to be able to help her husband support their family. As she continued with her business, the idea of putting up a general store came up, but she did not have sufficient capital to expand her business. This is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in August of 2000 - so that she could borrow additional capital to execute her plan of setting up a general store and increasing her income potential. Over the years, Leonisa’s diligence in paying back her loans on time gave her the opportunity to continue increasing her loan amount at each new cycle. With each new loan, she was able to expand and diversify her business ventures, which included raising livestock. She was able to go into different ventures because her children and her husband were very supportive and were at hand to help her manage the businesses. Her current activities earns her a monthly income of PHP 8,000. For her previous loan she borrowed Php 18,000 which she used fully as additional capital for her businesses and the loan was fully paid on time without any delays. This reinforced her good credit record with NWTF-Project Dungganon. For her 16th loan she plans to borrow Php 18,000 as additional capital for her general store and other ventures. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her businesses

loans.name: Tumurbat

texts.en:
Tumurbat P. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two young daughters in Uvurhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His eldest daughter is 10 and goes to a primary school. The youngest daughter is just four and stays home.

Tumurbat, a trained shoe-maker, repairs shoes for man and women at the central black market where he is busy with new and revisiting customers. He purchases raw materials such as leather and cotton from the wholesale markets in the city. Tumurbat says that with his profit, he would like to open a saving account and start putting aside some money. He requests a loan to purchase more raw materials for his shoe-making.

Thus, Mrs. Vorn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy duck food for her husband’s business.

Mrs. Vorn S. is 37 years old and is the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the other one stays at home to help the parents with housework.

Tsendsuren runs a small convenient store located on the piece of land that she owns and her small house is built. She has been in the food retail business since 1995. She has started selling various small food products as traveling to countryside and visiting individual families. In 2007, with help of her husband, she opened a small store and sells various food products, including soft-drinks, candies, etc. She mostly purchases her inventory products from local wholesale markets. She says that her business has been fruitful and the main source of income for her family. She further says that she would like to grow her small store into a nice supermarket with more choices of products. 
She requests a loan to purchase more inventory products for her store.

loans.name: Nenedta

texts.en:
Nenedta M. is from the village of Colupan Settlement, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old. Nenedta is married and has 3 adult-aged children.

To make a living, Nenedta owns & operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Nenedta has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 6,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nenedta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenedta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Nenedta is requesting a new loan of 6,000.00 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nenedta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Agua

texts.en:
Agua S. is currently in the business of selling plastic plates at the shop and is requesting a loan to purchase cups and spoons to sell.  Angua is 42 years old and is Married with a husband that is a nurse. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

loans.name: Vong's Group

texts.en:
This loan is requested by two low-income people. Mrs. Vong S., 47, has been selected to be a leader. Vong S. is the mother of seven children.  Four are married and live separately and another three are employed as garment workers. Vong S. is married to Heang, 49, who is a local construction worker. 
 Since her parents were alive, Vong S. has worked a plot of farming land. This year has been luckier for the local farmers because there has been enough rain to grow and harvest rice. Vong S. would like a loan to buy fertilizer and rice to grow on her field. 
The other member of this group, Prum S., 59, earns a living by selling past fish at the market.  She would like a loan to buy a machine for her daughter's sewing clothe.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice for growing on her field

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia C. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and business woman. She runs a tailoring mart sewing different types of clothes for both women and men. She also does school uniforms and other clothes for children.

The business area is at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business materials from both retail and wholesale shops at Kigamboni and Kariakoo city shopping center.

The business income helps her run her daily life and business capitalization. She needs a loan of TZS 600,000 to buy more business materials.

loans.use: To buy more business materials

loans.name: Bebialen

texts.en:
Bebialen Villarosa is 23 years old, single, and residing at Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City. Her livelihood and source of living is a barbecue food-vending business which she assumed from her mother.

Bebialen is a new member of PMPC and she joined the Co-op because of the good programs and services being offered. Right now she is applying for a loan of Php 20,000 as additional capital to purchase meat and ingredients for her business.

The profits of her business will be used for their living espenses and saved in the Co-op for her business’s future expansion.

loans.use: To purchase meat and ingredients for her barbecue-vending business

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza B. is from the village of Binuangan. She is 36 years old. Liza is married.

To make a living, Liza owns & operates a dried fish vending store, selling dried fish in the local community. Liza has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Liza joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC.

Liza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna N. is a villager in Kdey Tahok village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 0.5-hectare (1.25-acre) field on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this, she is a pig breeder.

Since her pig business is going well, Mrs. Vanna N. wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets. The rest of the loan she will use to buy pig food to feed them.

Mrs. Vanna N. is 63 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a driver who is able to make a small income to support the family, while the younger one stays at home to help with the pigs.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria B. is from the village of Libertad Alto,Sinacaban,Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old. Victoria is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Victoria owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising goats for sale. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 4,800.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Victoria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Victoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to build shelter for the borrower's livestock. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Victoria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the borrower's family.

loans.name: Kimlang

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimlang C. lives in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile so she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers. She will use the rest of the loan to buy rice soup and Khmer noodle ingredients to start a new business.

Mrs. Kimlang C. is 42 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a farmer while the younger one is attending the local school. Mrs. Kimlang C.’s husband, Mr. Em Sovann, helps her with the rice farming. He is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer plus ingredients to start a food business

loans.name: Purevjav

texts.en: B. Purevjav is 28 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. Her oldest daughter attends a local secondary school and her youngest is in kindergarden. Purevjav operates a firewood selling business in her town, while her husband runs a carpentry business. In Bayan-Ulgii province, there is much demand for their businesses as many residents live in gers and use firewood to heat their gers (Mongolian felt tent homes). Purevjav and her husband hire a driver and large truck, travel to a nearby forest, collect old wood, and transport it to the province center to sell. Her husband started his carpentry business in 2000 but already had much experience in the production after helping his father in the business since he was a child. Today, their businesses are very popular among the locals. For the future, Purevjav and her husband hope to start a small ger wall and supplies factory, as he has experience producing these products. She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~ 350 USD) loan to pay transportation fees for her firewood business.

loans.use: to pay transportation fees for her firewood business

loans.name: Fedelina

texts.en:
Fedelina G. is from Gango, city of Ozamiz. She is 50 years old and married to Olympio G.. They blessed with 3 adult-aged and 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Fedelina raised a small piggery to sustain their daily expenses and to support the education for their children. She has been engaged in this production for 8 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.


In March 2009, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial and other services of Paglaum to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000. PHP which will be used to buy more feeds for her swine production. This loan will be her 2nd loan taken out by Fedelina G. from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve their living situation and to live a healthy life.

loans.use: Use to buy more feeds for her swine production

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for groundnut and simsim.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Mrs. Alma P., 37 years of age, married is a resident of Migcanaway, Tangub City. She is blessed with 6 children all are in their teens and minor age. Her husband is a skilled fisherman equip with their own fishing nets and fishing boats. To help her husband in the support of the family, she engaged in fish vending activity from the catch of their fishing activity and also buying from other fishermen in the area. Presently, they were earning an average net income of not less than P6,000.00 a month from all this activity. As a new member, she is applying an amount of P4,000.00 to finance the repairs of their fishing boat and fishing nets. She is thankful to PAGLAUM MPC because of the trust given to her even if she is a new member and also for the trainings and education program of the coop.

loans.use: Repairs of fishing boat and fishing nets

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Mrs. Yen S. is a farmer in Cheav Phdey Kang Keit village in Takeo province. In her farming, she has a problem because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers for her purpose and she would use the rest of the loan to buy pesticides and hire laborers to work on the field. Her husband, Mr. Sovann Prum, helps on the farming. Mrs. Yen S. is 55 years old and the mother of two children one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the youngest one is attending the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizers for her purpose and she would use the rest of the loan to buy pesticides and hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha K. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and business woman. She runs a business buying and transporting crops from different regions in Tanzania and selling them in Dar es Salaam city market shopping center.

She purchases maize, beans and rice wholesale directly from the producers and sells to customers in Dar es Salaam in retail and wholesale. She has been in the business for the past six years. The business income has enabled her to buy a plot and construct a house. It also helps her meet her family's daily needs.

She needs a loan of TZS 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Mrs. Mut Nhaem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of sixteen people, is located in Roleang Kreul village in Takeo province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. M. N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. M. N. is farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates vegetables for a living. In the plantation, she now faces a problem because her field is not fertile, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizer to support the field. She will use the rest of the loan to buy cucumber seeds to grow. Her husband, Mr. Yos Hean, helps her on the farm. Mrs. M. N. does not have any children to help her.

Three members in this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and cucumber seeds

loans.use: To buy foam padding and cloth

loans.name: Adetom

texts.fr: Cette femme a appris le métier de la coiffure, elle est mariée. Elle a ouvert son propre atelier en 2006 qui fonctionne bien pour elle, la plupart des femmes de son quartier viennent se coiffer chez elle. Elle réalise de grosses recettes les week-ends. Elle a associé à cette activité le commerce de mèches et de produits défrisant qu’elle expose devant son atelier. Elle veut accroître son stock de produits de beauté et de mèches raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 10 cartons de mèches, des perruques et 20 défrisant de différentes marques.
texts.en:
This is a woman who learned the trade of hairdressing. She is married. She opened her own salon in 2006, and it’s working out well for her. Most of the women in her district go to have their hair done there. On weekends, she has a lot of income. Along with this business, she has included commerce in hair extensions and hair straighteners that she displays in front of her salon. She wants to increase her inventory of beauty products and hair extensions, which is why she’s requesting a WAGES loan, so as to buy 10 boxes of hair extensions, some wigs, and 20 straighteners of different brands.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions, wigs, and straighteners

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Tum Horm Group

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Tum H. is the leader of a group of four who are all living in Thmei Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Srey Tum H. is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field for cultivating rice to earn a living. Aside from this, she is also a silk weaver. On this plantation, she now faces a small problem because her field contains infertile soil, which has a bad effect on the crop. To solve this problem, Mrs. Srey Tum H. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, and she would use a portion of the loan to hire laborers to work in the field. For her silk weaving, she would buy more silk and other raw material to weave for her customers. Mrs. Srey Tum H. is a 31-year-old widow with three children, two of whom are weavers, and the youngest of whom is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and to hire laborers to work in the field

loans.name: Harrieth

texts.en: Harrieth C. is a married Tanzanian entrepreneur. She runs a foodstuffs shop at Tamata ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of foodstuffs to customers such as maize flour, wheat flour, beans, rice, sugar and cooking oil. She purchases the goods from wholesale and retail shops and sells to retail customers. She uses her business income for her family's daily needs. She has been in business for four years. She needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita Y. is from the village of Lusot. She is 62 years old. She is married. To make a living, she owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture engaged in farming. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from farm earnings.

In 2008, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from PMPC. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used for purchase of one carabao to assist in tilling her farm. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Teresita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from farming income to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family

loans.use: Purchase of 1 Carabao

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Acheter des produits de beauté, des mèches et un séchoir

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena B. is from the village of Sepac. She is 34 years old. Rowena is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Rowena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Rowena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver G. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Oliver is 39 years old and a widow. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal

loans.name: Marry

texts.en: Marry L. Mollel is an entrepreneur Tanzanian business married woman. She runs a business Designing, making and selling Traditional clothes (BATICK) and its product to customers. Also she runs a tailoring Mart as also a Teacher with three students. She has four sewing machines. Also she sells Tailoring business goods. She purchases the business materials from the shops in Kariakoo business center and selling to her customers. She needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to boost up the business

loans.use: To boost up the business by buying more business goods

loans.name: Rosamelina

texts.en:
Rosamelina B. is from the village of Salimpuno. She is 54 years old. Rosamelina is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosamelina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting  a cassava for sale. Rosamelina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Rosamelina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosamelina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Rosamelina is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to invest in their cassava plantation. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Rosamelina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest for cassava plantation project

loans.name: Genevieve

texts.en: Genevieve V. is from the village of Mauswagon. She is 50 years old. Genevieve is married and has 1 child. To make a living, Genevieve owns & operates a business venture.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling grocery items. Genevieve has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month for these activities. In 2000, Genevieve joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genevieve has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Genevieve is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional grocery supplies. This loan will be the 18th loan taken out by Genevieve from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.

loans.use: Additional grocery items for her grocery store

loans.name: Phares

texts.en: Pharesi Naftari is a small business Tanzanian married man. He runs cosmetics shops business at Mombasa ward in Dar es Salaam. He sells varieties of business goods at his shop and most of the customers are women as far as Dar es Salaam is hot. He purchases the business goods direct from the whole and retail sales shops. He has been in the business for three years. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to buy more business goods

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Gaudance

texts.en:
Gaudance N. is 34 years old ,married with two children aged between 10 to 12.
She lives in west province of Rwanda where she sells the small fishes since 1997 ,starting everyday from 6h00 AM to 7h00 PM .
Before this business she was a farmer and she could not  get all needs for his family.by the time she will get this loan requesting in vision finance company , Gaudance plans to purchase more small fishes for sales through more profit she will get ,she hopes to change the life of his family.

loans.use: purchasing more small fishes

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de bijoux et bracelets de différentes gammes. Une partie de son stock a baissé, pour la reconstituer, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter une vingtaine de bijoux et 10 bracelets montres.
Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants, avec le revenu de son commerce elle participe aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
Akossiwa A. sells watches and other jewelry in a variety of styles and quality. To replenish part of her inventory, she has requested a loan from WAGES to purchase twenty pieces of jewelry and 10 bracelet watches. She is married, and the mother of three children. The income from her business helps her contribute to the support of her family.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase jewelry and watches

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To restock food

loans.name: Ile

texts.en: Ile M. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread  and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking flour materials.  Ile is 32 years old and is Married with a husband that is a driver. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more baking flour

loans.name: Scolastica

texts.en: Scolastica J. is a married Tanzanian entrepreneur. She runs a phone accessories shop at Yombo Machimbo Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods from wholesale and retail sale shops at Kariakoo city business center and from other shops and sells to consumers at her shop. She has been in the business for three years and she uses the business income for her family's daily needs demand and for business capital. She needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to boost her business.

loans.use: To boost up the business

loans.name: Hanuvi Amélé

texts.fr: Cette femme est une couturière très expérimentée qui a débuté son activité depuis 2004. Elle a ouvert son atelier de couture dans le quartier de Baguida à Lomé ; elle est mariée à un caissier de bar et le couple a un enfant. Elle trouve du plaisir dans son activité puisqu’elle confectionne même des habits pour dames aux revendeuses d’habits, pour aller les vendre dans les différents marchés de Lomé. Elle dispose aussi d’une clientèle qui lui est fidèle et qui approuvent sa couture. Actuellement elle a besoin d’acheter au Grand Marché de Lomé 08 rouleaux de tissus et quelques articles de mercerie pour pouvoir confectionner de nouveaux habits pour dames et les vendre. C’est pour cela qu’elle pense qu’un crédit de WAGES lui permettra de réaliser ses nobles ambitions.
texts.en:
Mme. N. is a very experienced clothing designer who began her business in 2004. Her sewing studio is in the Baguida neighborhood of Lomé. She is the mother of one child. Hanuvi’s husband works as a cashier in a bar. She enjoys her work, which involves making clothing which she sells to other women who resell it in the markets of Lomé. She also has her own loyal clientele who love her clothes. She currently needs to purchase 8 roles of cloth and assorted sewing notions to make new outfits for women. She hopes a loan from WAGES will allow her realize her noble ambitions.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cloth and sewing notions

loans.name: Flavio Jaime

texts.pt:
Flávio Jaime M. nasceu em Boane um dos Distritos da Província de Maputo, que localiza se a 30 km da cidade, tem 32 anos de idade, estudou ate 5ª classe. Não foi possível continuar com os estudos, na altura o pai perdera a vida o único que sustentava todas as despesas. Vive maritalmente sustentando 3 filhos dos seus 6, 5 e 2 anos de idade todos frequentando a Escola, o de 2 anos na Escolinha. O filho de 6 e 2 anos são da outra mulher.

 Nunca mudou da cidade onde vive, em 1997 junta se com a primeira esposa a mãe de 2 filhos 6 e 2 anos, em 1999 junta se com a outra por sinal a mãe do menino de 5 anos. 
Na vida ele é agricultor dono de uma machamba e trabalhar desde 1995, tem 3 trabalhadores juntos trabalham cerca de 8 horas por dia. Adquiriu a experiência trabalhando num farmeiro desde 1993.

O repolho é o produto favorito, produzindo numa área de 80 metros quadrados, gastando ate 35mil meticais por campanha o que lhe rende cerca de 65 mil meticais. Depois de juntar a receita de outras culturas chega a somar 75 a 85 mil meticais por campanha, assim consegue poupar algum por mes.

Este é o quarto empréstimo do Flávio na Hluvuku no valor de 23.000,0mt para compra de insumos agrícolas (sementes, fertilizantes, pagamento de jornas de trabalho, preparação do solo e outros) embora tendo como desafios enfrentar pragas, roubo e a falta de transporte para o escoamento.
Os outros créditos foram pagos sem problemas (10.000,00mt; 20.000,00mt e 20.000,00mt) todos para a mesma actividade.

Para garantir os estudos das crianças, alimentação e outras despesas correntes precisa continuar apostando nesta actividade, sendo a única que consegue desenvolver, herdado dos pais. Assim pretende pedir mais financiamento no futuro para a compra de um carro para facilitar nos seus trabalhos agrícolas, principalmente o escoamento.
texts.en:
Flávio Jaime M. was born in Boane, a district in the province of Maputo. He is 32 years old and had to drop school before finishing 5th grade, when his father passed away and he had to start working to help support his family. He lives with his wife and children aged 2, 5 and 6, and all of them go to school. He has never left the city and he works with agriculture and owns a machamba (a large garden where crops are grown that provide most all the food for the people in the villages). He's been working since 1995 and has 3 employees, who work 8 hours a day. He got his work experience from working in a farm prior to that. His favorite vegetable is cabbage, which he grows in a 80km2 (80 square kilometers), and spending up to 35.000,00MT (U$1,275) each harvest, and making back around 65.000,00MT (U$2,365). Adding to that the other cultures, he's able to make up to 85.000,00MT (U$3,100) at the end of each harvest, which allows him to save some money. This is Flavio's 4th loan with Hluvuku in the amount of 23.000,00MT (U$850) to buy agricultural consumables (seeds, fertilizers, soil preparation) and also to pay his employees. He faces tough challenges like plagues, burglary and the lack of transportation for yielding. The other loans were paid in time and were all used for the same purpose. In order to guarantee his children proper food and education, he feels that he needs to keep investing in this business, as it is what he's good at. He plans on taking another loan in the future to buy a car to help with the business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Agricultural consumables (seeds, fertilizers)

loans.name: Hemed

texts.en: Hemed S. is a married Tanzanian businessman.  He runs a business making bricks and selling to customers at Kitunda Ward in Dar es Salaam. He makes the bricks by mixing sand and cement using special machines. Business materials are purchased from wholesale shops. He has been in the business for four years. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to buy more business materials. 10503

loans.use: To buy more construction materials

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Jean Damascene K. is 41 years old, married, and he takes care of six children aged between 2 and 18. He lives in Rubavu district, West Province, Rwanda.

Jean Damascene opens his business every day from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. and employs two persons. Before this, he was a farmer but he could not provide all his family’s needs. Now, with the loan requested from Vision Finance Company, he plans to purchase more goats which will help him to earn more profit so that he can expand his business, get more food for his family, save money for the future, and pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To buy more goats

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur a ouvert dans le quartier de Baguida à Lomé depuis 2001 un centre de blanchisserie ; cette activité lui permet surtout de subvenir aux besoins de sa femme et de son enfant. Beaucoup de clients apprécient le sérieux avec lequel il traite les vestes et la rigueur qu’il maintient dans son échéancier de remise des vestes et autres habits. Après 8 ans de vie professionnelle, il pense désormais procéder au réaménagement de son centre de blanchisserie ; pour cette raison, il a approché WAGES en vue d’obtenir un crédit pouvant lui permettre d’acheter une porte vitrée, de construire un hangar, d’acheter un autre séchoir à la mode et acquérir également d’autres accessoires indispensables. Ceci devrait d'aménager permettre d’aménager son atelier.
texts.en:
Mr. A. opened his laundry business in the Baguida neighborhood of Lomé in 2001. This activity allows him to support his wife and child. Many clients appreciate how responsibly he takes his work: both in the treatment of their suits and other clothing and the promptness of service. After eight years in business, he now wants to refurbish his establishment. For this reason, he approached WAGES to obtain a loan that would allow him to purchase a door with a window, to build a storage area, and acquire an additional clothes dryer and assorted other needed accessories. This would allow him to renovate his workplace.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a glass door, a clothes dryer and assorted cleaning supplies

loans.name: Able God 1 Group

texts.en:
Jaylee N. is the leader of a group of borrowers called Able God 1. He is 47 years old and is married with six children aged 5-25 years old, with educational levels of 9th grade through high school graduate.

Because Jaylee is illiterate, getting into business was an easier means for him and his family to survive. He has run his charcoal-selling business for four years, selling to the residents of Chicken Soup Factory, Gardnerville, in northern Monrovia, Liberia.

Having a good relationship with his customers has been the medium of attracting customers. However, the rainy season is the difficulty Jaylee faces because, when it rains, his charcoal gets wet and that is bad for business.

Jaylee needs this loan to purchase more bags of charcoal wholesale to expand his business. He dreams of establishing a bigger business that will enable him build a house and educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Miguel Mabila

texts.pt:
Miguel Mabila C. tem 51 anos de idade, Nasceu na Província de Maputo, no Distrito de Namaacha este que faz fronteira com a Suazilândia. Fez 6ª classe do antigo sistema que não foi possível continuar devido a varias razoes. Vive casada maritalmente e é pai de 4 filhos de 24, 22, 19 e 17 anos de idade dos quais 3 vão a escola. Para alem deste sustenta 1 sobrinho e uma tia, enviando lhe dinheiro. 

	Em 1960 sai de Namaacaha rumo a cidade capital, onde construiu o seu lar e continua a viver ate hoje, tem um estabelecimento comercial em Mahubo desde o ano 2000 onde dedica se das 8.00h as 19.00h permanentemente. Foi na base de uma empresa denominada MANOFATOS onde foi funcionário que ganhou esta larga experiência na arena comercial já a mais de 9 anos. O seu melhor produto é arroz, sal e óleo, onde os custos de aquisição para arroz são de 485.00, 530.00 para o óleo e 110.00 para o sal, revendendo a 540.00 para o arroz, 640.00 para o óleo e 150.00 para o sal. Através destes e outros produtos consegue cerca de 2.000.00 por mes e ainda poupar algum. 

            Este é o seu segundo empréstimo na Hluvuku que também conheceu esta instituição em conversa com seus amigos. Vive na sua própria casa e ainda não pediu nenhum empréstimo em outros bancos. Com 10.000.00mts espera aumentar o volume e diversificar cada vez mais os seus produtos, como desafios de fazer crescer e expandir o seu negócio, mas a falta de transporte ainda constitui um obstáculo, mas acredita que só seria possível com novos empréstimos.
texts.en:
Miguel Mabila C. is 51 years old and was born in Maputo, Mozambique. He studied until 6th grade. He is married and has 4 children aged 24, 22, 19 and 17; three of them are students. Besides his kids he also helps a nephew and an aunt by sending them money every month. Miguel moved to Maputo in 1960, built his home and started his business. He owns a shop in Mahubo where he works from 8AM to 7PM every day. He worked at a company called "Manofatos" prior to that, which is where he acquired all his experience in commerce. His best sellers are rice, salt and oil. By buying the products and reselling them at his shop he's able to make around 2.000,00MT (U$70) per month and is even able to save some. This is his second loan he's asking, in the amount of 10.000,00MT (U$375). He will use the money buy a bigger amount of merchandise and diversify his products, growing his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic food products for reselling (rice, salt, cooking oil, flour and others)

loans.name: Kokoè

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente des produits d’alimentation générale dans sa boutique située dans le quartier de Kagomé à Lomé. Grâce à ce commerce qu’elle a débuté depuis 2006, elle apporte sa part financière dans son foyer ; elle est en effet mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé et vend du riz en détail, des savons, des œufs et même de la boisson locale alcoolisée dénommée « sodabi ». Parce qu’elle accueille bien ses clients, sa boutique est très fréquentée presque par tous les gens du quartier. Elle nécessite en ce moment de renouveler son stock qui s’épuise ; c’est pour ce motif qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 40 litres de « sodabi », 01 sac de riz et divers produits comme les tomates en boîtes et d’autres boîtes en conserve. Elle n’a aucune inquiétude pour le remboursement.
texts.en:
Mme. S. sells food in her boutique in the Kagomé neighborhood of Lomé. Thanks to the business, which she launched in 2006, she contributes to the financial support of her household. She is married with 3 children. She purchases her stock at the Grand Marché of Lomé. She sells rice in small quantities, soaps, eggs, and a local alcoholic beverage called “sodabi.” Because she takes good care of her clients, her boutique is popular with almost everyone in the neighborhood. Her inventory is getting low. This is why she has requested a loan from WAGES, to purchase 40 liters of “sodabi,” one bag of rice, and various products such as canned tomatoes and other canned foods. She is quite confident about her ability to repay the loan.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food for resale

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha S. is a married Tanzanian woman entrepreneur. She runs a business buying and selling traditional clothes (Kanga and Vitenge) at Yombo Kiwalani ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases direct from the wholesale shops at Mnazi Mmoja shopping center and sells retail to customers. She also runs a business as a food vendor. She has been running the business for the past four years. She meets her family's daily demands through the business income generated. She is asking for a loan of 800,000 TZS to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 27 year old business woman who owns a boutique in Nairobi. She has been in this business for the last four years. She is requesting for a first loan of Kes. 30,000 in order to add stock of shoes. A mother of one, Grace hopes to educate her child to the highest level  using her business profits, buy a home for her family and buy rental units. She describes herself as social hard working and determined.


About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock
